text:
AARTI PORWAL: The Center
for Health education, broadly speaking, has a mission
to extend world class health education to a global network
of health professionals,

individuals, and communities,
creating a more informed public and improving health
outcomes and to create

learning experiences that
offer essential health knowledge for
working professionals

and the general public probably
out around three main focus

areas. First, we have courses that
tackle of the future of health

and data science. We think a lot about how
health care has changed and where it is going, and
how we can upskill and prepare

people to practice
in a new ecosystem, whether you're already
working in the industry or looking to start a new
career in health care.

The health landscape
is constantly evolving, and we must shift to
understand, for example, how new technology like AI
and machine learning

are influencing the space. How health informatics
is advancing as we consider big
data and its impact

on how we process information
and make decisions, or how new treatments
and personalized medicine are options now with
revolutionary fields

like genomics and
precision medicine. In this vertical,
we currently have offerings in medical statistics,
AI and health care, applications

and machine learning in
healthcare, digital health product development, clinical
trials management, foundations

and advanced courses in genetics
and genomics and telehealth.

Second portfolio. With an explosion of
information on health and wellness out
there, our main goal

is to provide concrete
learning experiences that are evidence-based
and that can help advance health and wellness globally.

In this portfolio, we
have offerings and things like nutrition
science that teach you to understand
and apply evidence

to a wide variety of
nutrition scenarios that can help you understand
the science behind things like addiction and recovery,
high performance, child

development, the role of
positivity in wellness, and many other subjects
that focus on overall

how to keep our
community's health. And third, we have our
management and leading course

portfolio. In this focus area,
we help leaders strategize on how to advance
their teams and skills to be

effective and competitive in our
current and future health care environments. We cover topics like overall
leadership, diversity, equity,

and inclusion in health care,
management and teaching. I hope this helps
explain how we think

about our overall portfolio. And next, I'll briefly review
the various types of offerings

and learning experiences. Through Stanford
Online, we have learning experiences that fit various
types of learning styles

and needs from free
on-demand rapid learning all the way to online
graduate certificates and master's degrees that
apply the same time commitment

and level of rigor as
residential students here at Stanford. Starting here at the
left, this visual

helps clarify how we think
of the continuum of learning and the differences
in learning style, price point, certification,
and time commitment.

As we move up from the three
rapid learning opportunities, we offer several
courses that fall

in the professional
certificate stage. The second column,
self-paced courses,

typically involves one
deep dive in a topic. For example, digital
health product development or clinical trials,
and is designed

to be done on your
own time and schedule. You will receive a
record of completion that can be shared on LinkedIn
or added to your resume.

Because certain
topics lend themselves better to peer
learning, we do offer some scheduled cohort-based
professional courses.

Although these are
still on-demand, you must take the offering
in a set schedule, for example, six
weeks or eight weeks,

so that you can interact with
peers as a group in discussion topics, and have the added
benefit of a learning

facilitator guiding
your journey. These experiences will earn you
a certificate of completion.

The last of our
professional courses is for programs that
typically consist of a minimum of
three courses that

cover not just one topic,
but a more advanced learning and holistic series. For example, rather than
taking a single course

on digital health
product development, you can take a full
health innovation program that also covers how
to test that product

through clinical trials
design, and understand how the data can inform
strategic product development.

We currently have programs on
medical statistics, genetics, artificial intelligence, machine
learning, and health innovation.

Toward the right
of the graphic, we cover both graduate certificates
and online master's degrees, which again, are
the same courses

that residential
Stanford students take. But we make them
available online for working professionals.

These programs will earn
you a Stanford transcript and do require an
application to pursue. My colleague Pax
will go more in depth

with these graduate offerings
later in the webinar. Now that we've shared a
portfolio and the types

of learning
experiences we offer, I'd invite you to check out the
link to the right of your screen that takes you to a visual
that maps each of our topics

to the type of offering
we currently have. As a reminder, you can
always get much more detail about each individual program
by visiting online.stanford.edu.

I'm going to pass it
now to Jackie Peterson to review some of our featured
programs more in depth with you.

Back to you, Jackie. JACKIE PETERSON:
Thank you, Aarti. As Aarti mentioned, we
have many, many courses

and programs offered through our
health and medicine portfolio. Today I'll be diving
a little deeper into a select few of our
professional programs offered

through the Center
for Health Education. The first of these is our
Genetics and Genomics programs.

Our Genetics And
genomics courses have been divided
into two programs. The first is our Foundations of
Genetics and Genomics Program,

which is designed to be
beginner-level and give you a foundational understanding of
fundamental concepts in genetics

and genomics. Taught by a group of both
scientists and Stanford professors, this
two-course program

will prepare you to explore
more advanced topics as you move forward
in your journey and is highly recommended
as a starting point

if you don't already have
a background in genetics. The second program, which is
advanced topics in genetics

and genomics, will introduce
you to more in-depth topics such as stem cell therapeutics,
CRISPR, gene therapy,

genetic engineering and
biotechnology, epigenetics and microbiomics, and more. Taught by Stanford professors
and industry experts,

this program will provide you
with up-to-date information on cutting edge research and
technologies in the health and medicine industries.

And this advanced program
offers eight courses that can be taken
either individually or you can enroll in
our all access program

and complete at least
five of the eight courses to earn a certificate
of achievement. And both programs
are self-paced.

You can begin at any time. Moving on to our next topic
area, health innovation.

We offer several courses
to help you discover how health innovation can unlock
the future of health care, driving transformative
change in industry practices,

patient care, and beyond. Our first course in digital
health product development will teach you about the
product development process,

intellectual property
rights, and how to avoid common quality
and regulatory pitfalls. This course will cover needs
finding, concept generation,

and go to market all within
the digital health landscape. And our next course
in this topic bucket,

our clinical trials course, will
cover frameworks and reporting methods to determine how to
accurately collect, manage,

and measure data. You'll gain the knowledge
necessary to understand the components that
go into running a successful clinical trial.

This course is valuable for
anyone in a patient-facing role looking to implement research
into your professional career,

or if you're seeking how
to better communicate and collaborate with
colleagues working in the labs. This course uses real-life
examples and case studies

to help you understand and apply
the principles of clinical trial design, ensure diverse
representative study

populations, minimize bias,
and ensure trial reliability and validity, and use effective
data collection and management

techniques. And our third course
in this program, demystifying data,
a modern approach

to statistical understanding,
will launch in August quarter. And this foundational
statistics course

provides a practical
toolkit for professionals who apply, interpret, or
engage with statistics

and data-based evidence in
their job or daily life. This course will incorporate
example data sets

from varied domains, including
medicine, health care, business, government, education,
social science, and psychology.

This course will emphasize
concepts and intuition over formulas and
does not require any statistical programming.

But you'll learn to peer under
the hood of statistical claims, reports, and dashboards
to ask critical questions.

And all three of
these courses can be taken individually or
as an all access program. They're all offered
as open enrollment,

meaning you can
start at any time. And they're all self-paced.

Our next topic bucket
is our AI portfolio. And this begins with our
beginner-level program in AI

in health care. This program is offered
through the Center for Health Education on
the Coursera platform, and it's available on
a subscription basis.

This program includes
five courses, including intro to health care,
intro to clinical data, fundamentals of machine
learning for health care,

evaluations of AI
applications in health care, and AI in health
care capstone, which

will help you apply the
knowledge that you've learned. These courses are taught by
Stanford professors and industry

experts. It's highly rated
on the platform. It's also self-paced and
can be completed on a course

by course basis. It's a great place to begin your
journey into AI in health care.

But if you already
have a background in AI or you've taken the
AI in health program and you're looking to dive
deeper into AI and health

topics, we are about to
launch our new open enrollment self-paced applications of
machine learning and medicine

program. This program will
be launching soon and includes two courses in data
foundations and machine learning

and medicine and model
deployment, development deployment and considerations. And this program is taught
by Professor Nigam Shah.

It's based on content from his
popular grad course in data science for medicine.

You'll learn to work
with health care data and how to use data to
conduct research studies, differentiate between categories
of research questions,

and the study designs
used to address them. You'll describe common
health care data sources and their
advantages and limitations

relative to different
research questions, extract and transform various
kinds of clinical data

to create analysis-ready
data sets, and execute tasks involving
data manipulation and analysis.

You'll then apply your knowledge
through hands-on programming assignments using R.
You can take these two

courses individually
or as a program to earn a certificate
of achievement as well.

Again, we offer many
more professional courses in health and wellness
through our center. You're welcome to visit
our website to check out

more of our offerings. And feel free to reach out
should you have any questions. I'll now pass it on
to my colleague Pax

to talk more about our
graduate offerings. Pax. PAX HEHMEYER: Thanks, Jackie. Thanks, Aarti.

And just a reminder, if
you have any questions, feel free to put them in
the QA box right there.

We'll answer a couple
of them here aloud. And then we also have some
of our colleagues joining

who can answer directly if you
have a specific question that is maybe about a course you took.

So my name is Pax Hehmeyer. I oversee the credit
bearing courses that are part of the
Stanford Online portfolio.

And so I'm going to
give you what I'm going to talk a little bit about. I won't go in as much detail
about the specific courses.

I want to give you an overview
of what that experience is like, who might be interested
in these kinds of courses. And I'll go in a little bit
more detail about what we offer.

And then finally,
I'm going to end on just talking a little
bit about how you would apply if you are interested. And I will just say it now,
I'll say it again at the end.

If you are interested, the
enrollment for the fall quarter is open now and
close September 8.

There's a little link to
the right of your screen where you can click to look
at the whole portfolio.

And that will show
you everything from the self-paced to the
credit bearing courses. And you can filter to just
see one particular type

if you're interested. All right. So what are the credit bearing
courses at Stanford Online?

So this is your opportunity
to take a class from Stanford.

These are the same classes
that are happening on campus. And we are extending
them to online learners

to make them available
to working professionals or to people who
just don't have time to pursue a course or
graduate studies full time,

or may not want to. Maybe you do have the time, but
you don't want to at this point. It's a pretty
unique opportunity.

And I use that word extended
the on-campus course to online students, but it's
not an extension program.

So you will earn a
Stanford transcript. And you are
responsible for doing the same assignments
and the same work

that the on-campus
students are doing. You are doing the
same things and you're earning the same transcript.

And for the focus
of this, I'm not going to talk about
the master's degree. I'm going to talk about what
we call our non-degree option

program. So you're not admitted
into Stanford, but you are earning a
Stanford transcript. You're taking the same courses
and you're pursuing them

as an online student. So what does that look like? Well, at core, you
get a Stanford email,

Stanford log in
credentials, and you then are following
along with the rest

of the students for whom
much of the course material already is online. So you're going to
submit the assignments.

They're going to be distributed
and submitted online, the course assignments. You're going to be participating
in the same online forums

and discussion
areas where students are posting questions
that are then answered by the faculty or the TAs.

You will be joining
office hours. They'll have a
certain number that are online office hours that
you will be able to join

over Zoom typically. The lectures are the
one big difference where we are recording
them in a classroom.

And occasionally,
they're pre-recorded. And if they're
pre-recorded, they're pre-recorded for everybody. But for the most
part, we're recording

them live in the classroom. You can live stream it. But for most of our
students, they're watching it after the
fact because, you're

a working professional. You have a job from 9:00 to
5:00 or you're in New York or you're in India or you're in
Europe and you can't join a 1:00

PM Pacific time lecture. So you watch that recording. You are following
the same deadline.

So it's not like you can wait
10 weeks to watch that lecture recording. You're going to probably
watch it fairly soon after.

There may be limited
opportunities to participate live in
those lecture recordings. Usually it's just the
recording is available.

You can download it, watch
it at your convenience. But basically, beyond that,
you're doing the same work

and doing the same things
as the other students. You're joining
those office hours. If you have project
work, maybe you're connecting with the
on-campus students

and you're meeting over Zoom,
you're meeting over Slack, or if you're local, maybe
you're meeting in person

to do that project work. You're joining a
study groups just like the on-campus students,
and to do your homework.

You're doing the same things. Now we do recognize that is both
an opportunity and a challenge.

It's an opportunity because
you're taking the same courses and you're held to
the same standard

and you're earning
the same transcript.  It is also a challenge
because, of course,

there are students
who are sitting in the class who can walk
up to the podium at the end and ask a question. And you are an online student.

You don't have that flexibility
or you don't have that option. We do have things like
regular orientations

and a Slack channel
just dedicated to online students that do help
provide support to make sure

that you can be successful
in those classes as an online student. So that's kind of an overview
of what that experience is like.

So I'm seeing there's some
good questions coming in.

So I'll come back to
those in a little bit. So that's an overview of
what that experience is like.

So let me talk a little bit
about who this might be for. What are the kinds
of students we see who are interested in
enrolling in these programs?

So the typical
student is one who is interested in
graduate studies, who

wants more rigor than maybe you
can get from an online course because they want to be
able to ask a TA a question

or go to an office hours or
they want to be kind of forced to do a problem set every
week in order to really

learn and master the material. And actually, let me pause
here and say that we recognize that's also not for everybody.

And for that reason, a lot
of the graduate programs that we have, we also
have self-paced versions.

So Jackie mentioned
that Professor Shah, who teaches in our biomedical
data science graduate program,

is a professor here, also has
some self-paced online offerings that you can do. So maybe you're just
interested in the material

and you don't need all
that other support, great, you have that option too. Similarly, Kristin
Sainani, who is

one of the professors in
the epidemiology program, in our epidemiology
graduate certificate,

she also has online programs. You can enroll in that. You can do it at your own pace
and really learn that material

as it fits you. So as Aarti said, we've
built out a portfolio to give you a lot
of different options

and the kinds of learning
experiences you can pursue. All right, so who is
interested in this?

Who do we find is right for this
kind of learning experience? So again, it's
often people who are

interested in
graduate education, but maybe not quite
yet interested or ready for a master's degree.

And so the advantage
of this program is that you do have some
flexibility about when

you take courses, how
many courses you take, and which courses you take. So let me walk through that.

If you are enrolled
in a master's program, you have to take courses
typically every single quarter, and you have to take a
minimum number of units.

If you're interested in taking a
course as a non-degree student, you can apply any
quarter that we offer

a course you're interested in. If you're approved to take the
course, you can take the course and then you don't need to
take a course the next quarter.

So there are a lot
of students who say, maybe you're-- so there are a
lot of students who are just interested in a single
course, but they want, again,

that rigor of a
graduate level course. And so this is something
that's valuable to them. There may be other
students who, again,

are interested in maybe more
than just a single course. Maybe they want to
choose multiple courses, but they don't want to pursue
a specific program of study.

Well, this gives
you that option. You can take a course
in computer science. You can take a course
in epidemiology.

You can take a course
in chemical engineering. You can piece it
together-- as long as you're approved to
take those courses,

you can piece together
a learning experience that's right for you or a
curriculum that's right for you.

Now you can also pursue
these graduate certificates, which are accredited and which
you earn for two or three--

or excuse me, three or four
courses, sometimes five.

So that's another
direction you can go. And the last thing I'll
say about who it's for is also these--

is there are lots of
students who may be interested in graduate school. Maybe they're even interested
in master's degree at Stanford.

And so they want to try it out. So you take a course. And you see if
it's right for you. And then if it is
right for you, you

apply to the master's degree. And even if you're
interested in online degree, it's the same application, you
apply to the master's degree.

And then if you're admitted,
you can apply up to 18 units that you've completed
as a non-degree student

towards those master's degrees. And so it's a wonderful
way essentially for you to test out
your graduate education

and maybe to dig a
little bit deeper. You can think of
maybe right now, you're coming to us and you are
an epidemiologist or a health

care specialist and you've done
a lot of work on population data, but you don't--

this AI stuff is
all new for you. And you've done a lot of
the self-paced things. You have a good
understanding, but you really

need something rigorous. And you need something
more rigorous than you can find in other places. You're not just interested in
the latest Python libraries

that you use for
machine learning. You're interested
in understanding it at a very deep level.

You're interested in being able
to write the mathematical proofs for some of these ideas. You're interested really in
understanding optimization

or whatever all these different
aspects of machine learning are. So that could be an
example where you say,

OK, I'm bringing that
medical background. I'm going to take this class,
this graduate-level class in machine learning
from Stanford

and I'm going to get a really
deep understanding of that. On the other hand, maybe
you're a computer scientist,

you're a programmer,
and you're working at a pharmaceutical
company and you have a strong
computational background,

but you don't have
a lot of background in the domain knowledge
around medicine or around population health.

And maybe in particular,
you're interested in learning about clinical
trials and how you work through clinical trials,
what's required for them.

And of course, you can read
blog posts, you can read books, you can do all those
kinds of things, but you want something that's
a little bit more rigorous.

Well, great. We have clinical trial classes. And maybe you're
just someone who's interested in epidemiology. It's obviously been
a very hot topic

and you're interested in
a graduate certificate. So maybe you want to take
three or four courses and make a career
shift into epidemiology

from, say, nursing or
something, an adjacent field. So those are examples
of the kinds of students

that we see who are interested
in taking graduate-level courses online from Stanford.

So let me dig a little
bit deeper into our core-- actually, before I jump
ahead, at a high level,

so what we have in terms
of the offerings that are available is within
the School of Medicine, we have about 20 courses.

We have two certificates. And I'm going to dig into
those in a little bit. And we do have one
master's degree that you can complete
online, and that's

in biomedical data science. Our full catalog is much bigger. We're primarily in the
School of Engineering,

so we have a lot of
engineering courses. The computer science,
chemical engineering, electrical
engineering, et cetera.

We have about 30
certificates there and we have 11 master's degrees. Not all of those can be
completed fully online,

but many of them can be
completed either online or partly online. So let me dig into a
little bit more detail

about the specific School
of Medicine programs.

So the first is epidemiology. And again, as I said,
Kristin Sainani, who is a professor
here, she also

has self-paced offerings
that you can take. But she's one of the professors
within the epidemiology program.

I won't go into too much depth
about what epidemiology is, but it's the cornerstone
of population health,

as well as
evidence-based medicine. And this particular
certificate program is based around the
core requirements

of the epidemiology
master's degree at Stanford. And so you can see, this will
update and change each year.

We're just launching our fall. So this will probably
have some changes. But the required courses
are around biostatistics

and clinical trial design and
clinical research methods. And you take those courses,
you choose an elective.

And again, they're
feeling like these are some of the
core requirements to give you a strong
foundation in epidemiology.

If you are interested in the
master's degree after this, you could apply to
the master's degree. It's not an online degree.

But you would have
something like 12 out of 45 units
completed already. If you did get into
the master's degree,

you could apply them
towards that master's degree if you were admitted. So that's epidemiology.

The other program where we
offer a graduate certificate and we do have an online
master's degree for

is biomedical data science. And so biomedical data
science is this merging

of several
disciplines, including biomedical informatics,
computer science, biostatistics,

and a lot of the recent advances
in artificial intelligence. And biomedical data science
takes that intersection

and tries to apply it to a
whole range of the entire--

a whole range of data across
the entire medical spectrum. So including things
like medical imaging,

electronic health records,
tissue analysis, image analysis.

So it's really applied to a
whole broad range of data. And so you can think
there's a lot of overlap

between epidemiology and
biomedical data science. I think data science is probably
a bit more computationally heavy

than epidemiology and
applies its methods to a broader range of topics
potentially than epidemiology.

But very similar-- or
excuse me, but there is a fair amount of overlap. So those are the two
core sets of programs

that we have in the
School of Medicine that are available to learners who
are interested in getting know,

credit bearing, earning a
transcript, and potentially a graduate certificate. And maybe applying and being
admitted to down the road

a master's degree. So what is it? So maybe you've heard
this and you say,

I am interested
potentially in pursuing one of these credit
bearing courses. As I mentioned, our fall
enrollment is open right now.

It closes on September 8. So you have about a month
to make that decision. And again, this is
another piece of what's

flexible and nice about this. You can apply and
enroll in a course any quarter that a
course is offered.

So right now all
you'd have to do is log on, go to Stanford
Online, create an account, and fill out an application.

The application is not nearly
as intensive as something like applying to
a master's degree. We don't need GRE
scores or TOEFL scores.

What we need is a short
statement of purpose. We need your
educational background. We will need
official transcripts.

We need some
personal information like residency documents, your
passport photo, those kinds of-- or your passport
page, not your photo,

as well as your
professional background. So once you've submitted
that application to us, you then go enroll
in a course and then

we send that application
out to the department. Now every time you
enroll in a course, we do send that application
back to the relevant department

to review. And they will look at
it and they'll say, does this person meet
our minimum requirements? Does this person meet
the prerequisites

for this particular course? And if you do, all
things considered,

then they will approve
you to take that course. The next time you see a
course you want to take,

we'll send that
application back out to you or back out to the department,
the relevant department,

as well as your
Stanford transcript so they can see how you've
been doing in Stanford courses. And they'll review
it again and then

they'll approve in that kind
of course by course basis. The general rule of thumb
is once you're approved and you're meeting
the prerequisites,

you need to get a B or better
to continue taking classes through the non-degree program.

But again, you can
apply any time. It's a much shorter application. And you can enroll
any quarter or course

that you're interested
in is offered. So maybe you go look
at the offerings that are available now for the
fall and there's nothing there

that strikes your fancy. You can take a look
again in winter. You can take a look again
in spring or in the summer and apply at those times.

So I'm going to stop there. I think that's it for my
spiel about the credit
bearing programs. I see we have--

I see we have a
couple questions here. So I'll address a
few-- let me jump

to this next one, a few that are
related to the credit bearing

program. So let me just start with
the question about, which ones are the graduate
level courses that will show up on a transcript?

So when you go, there's
a link to your left that shows that's a
link to our courses

and it'll take you to
our course catalog. You can then filter
by credential.

And one of them is an
academic transcript. So I would filter
by that and that'll show you the courses
that are available,

maybe not for
enrollment now, but are available in general
for enrollment and you'll earn a Stanford
transcript for them.

I see this about
customizing a program. We don't have-- so I did say
you can build a curriculum that

matches what you are interested
in at the graduate level. You can't build
your own program, but you can just take classes.

And as long as you continue to
be approved for those classes, that's OK. So again, you don't have
to pursue a certificate.

You don't have to pursue
a particular program plan. You could take machine
learning from computer science and then take clinical trials
design from epidemiology.

And then you could take
biomedical data science from the biomedical
data science program.
Let's see what some other--

I see a great question
for the master's degree. I'm actually not
sure what the time gap is for a course to be
applied to the master's degree.

It's probably-- I'll
have to look into that to get a more precise answer. In terms of earning the
graduate certificates,

you need to complete
all the coursework within two to three years. And if you would be admitted
into a master's degree,

you'd have about-- as a part-time student, you'd
have three to five years to complete the
rest of the degree.

The graduate courses are not-- I'm not sure. I think you're referring
to STAP for Stanford funds.

The graduate courses, I don't
believe are STAP eligible. And a I saw there was a
question about pricing.

For graduate courses, there's
a standard-- the tuition, which is full tuition is
$1,514 per unit for the class.

And the differences
you saw quoted on those slides between
the two programs is just one graduate
certificate requires

about 12 units and another I
think only requires 9 or 10. And so that's the
difference in the cost

of those graduate certificates. And it can vary depending
on which courses you choose to take. So if you took 404 unit classes
to satisfy the requirements
